segments.summary: This segment explains Gandhari's decision to enter the fire of her dead husband, known as the Sati rite, highlighting it as a voluntary act of a chaste wife who finds separation from her husband more unbearable than death.
segments.transcript: The meaning of this verse is, while outside observing her husband who will burn in the fire of mystic power along with his thatched cottage, his chaste wife Gandhari will enter the fire with rapt attention. So, now already Narada has told Yudhishthira, Dhritarashtra will follow the yogic process and quit the body and the body will be burnt by the self-generated fire through the mystic power. Now, along with Dhritarashtra's body burning, the thatched cottage in which he was sitting and performing his austerity or the practice itself will burn. And what will Gandhari do? She is not practicing any yoga. She is just faithfully as a chaste wife following her husband. So, Srila Prabhupada explains, Gandhari was an ideal chaste lady, a life companion of her husband. And therefore, when she saw her husband burning in the fire of mystic yoga along with his cottage of leaves, she despaired. Naturally, wife is very faithfully serving the husband and the husband quits, it's a big loss for the wife because she has always been with him as a chaste wife and she has been serving him. Now, what will she do when he is no longer present in the form as the husband? So, it says here, Srila Prabhupada explains, She left home after losing her 100 sons and in the forest she saw that her most beloved husband was also burning. She lost her sons in the battle of Krukshetra. Our husband also, he quit his body which was a self-generated fire, through mystic yoga practice. What will she do? So, Prabhupada says, Now she actually felt alone and followed her husband to death. She decided to also quit the body now. This entering of a chaste lady into the fire of a dead husband is called the sati rite. You would have heard this term sati, sati, sati ritual, sati rite. What is it? The wife has lost her husband and does not have any surviving sons. Such a wife, if she is a chaste woman, she will enter the fire of her dead husband and quit her body voluntarily and the action, this sati ritual or the sati rite, is considered to be the most perfect for a woman. segments.key_quote: Having spoken thus, the great sage Nārada, along with his veena, ascended into outer space. Yuriṣṭira kept his instruction in his heart and so was able to get to the fall lamentation.
segments.summary: This segment discusses Narada's ascension to outer space, Yudhishthira's overcoming lamentation through Narada's instructions, and Narada's role as an eternal spaceman who travels to preach the message of Krishna and liberate people.
segments.transcript: Pradhyatesh has around food und Gen-beav. no more inimical feeling towards devotees or the Supreme Lord. The last verse of this chapter, sixtieth verse, ityuktvā atha āruhat svargam nārada sahatumburuhu yuriṣṭiro vachastasya hṛdī pritvā jahā chuchah. The meaning of this last verse, sixtieth verse is, Having spoken thus, the great sage Nārada, along with his veena, ascended into outer space. Yuriṣṭira kept his instruction in his heart and so was able to get to the fall lamentation. Yuriṣṭira was lamenting that my uncle left home and went away. I don't know where he has gone. Nārada informed him where Dhritarashtra has gone. Nārada informed him what will happen to Dhritarashtra. That Dhritarashtra will be liberated. And therefore, Yuriṣṭira, keeping the instruction of Nārada in his heart, he became free from all lamentation. Now, Nārada is described here by Prabhupāda as an eternal spaceman. He is having a spiritual body, endowed by the Supreme Lord himself. He can travel in outer space of both the material and the spiritual worlds. He is free to travel anywhere without any restrictions and he can approach any planet, either in the material world or the spiritual sky. Spiritual sky are the Vaikuntha Lokas. In the material world, there are different kinds of upper planetary systems: Svarga Loka, Maharloka, Janaloka, Tapoloka, Brahmaloka, or the earthly planets, Bhūloka, Bhūvarloka, or even the lower planets, Atala, Vitala, Sutala, anywhere he can go. And why does he travel? He simply travels to preach the message of Kṛṣṇa about bhakti and to deliver people, to liberate people from material bondage.

segments.key_quote: You should follow in the footsteps of Nārada Muni. Become a devotee and go back to the spiritual kingdom of Kṛṣṇa.
segments.summary: This segment encourages listeners to follow Narada Muni's example by becoming devotees and returning to the spiritual kingdom of Krishna to engage in loving devotional service.
